experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I'll be honest—I'm pretty nervous about this, but I know I need to get better at, like, talking to people, especially if I want to get into a good grad school.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
Hey Gregory! First off, it’s totally normal to feel nervous—I’ve been there too. Since you're already low in social anxiety, that’s a great starting point! For public speaking, try joining a club like Toastmasters or practicing in smaller settings first. It builds confidence gradually.

For grad school, focus on building relationships with professors during office hours—they can become mentors and write strong recommendation letters. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I guess. I'm just worried about bothering professors during office hours when they're probably busy. And Toastmasters sounds... really intense for a first step.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
That's a fair concern! Professors actually expect students to come to office hours—it shows initiative. Start with a specific question about coursework or research interests to make it productive.

For public speaking, you could try smaller steps first, like speaking up in study groups or class discussions. Baby steps build confidence without pressure. You're capable of this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try asking about that algorithm we're stuck on in study group first... It's just hard to shake the feeling I'm bothering them, even if it's their job.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message:
Exactly! Starting with study groups is perfect—it’s low-pressure and directly relevant. Remember, your peers likely have the same questions, so speaking up helps everyone.

As for professors: they chose this career because they want to support students. You’re not a bother; you’re engaging. Keep it brief and prepared, and you’ll build that mentor relationship naturally. You’ve got great self-awareness—use it to your advantage!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... it's just hard to believe everyone else is as nervous as I am. I'll try to ask one question in my algorithms study group this week.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a solid plan! Remember, many students feel the same way but just don't show it. Asking one question is a great first step—it'll feel easier each time. Celebrate small wins! You're taking proactive steps, and that's what matters most. Keep it up!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess you're right. It's just hard to believe everyone else is nervous when they all seem so put together. I'll try asking one question in my algorithms class tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's the spirit! Remember, "put together" is often just a front—everyone's navigating their own doubts. Asking one question is a brave step forward. You're building skills that will help in grad school interviews and beyond. Rooting for you tomorrow!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I guess. I just hope I don't freeze up and actually ask the question. Grad school interviews feel so far away when I'm just trying to get through tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally get that—grad school can feel abstract when you're tackling today's hurdles. If you freeze, that's okay! Even preparing a question on a notecard can help. Focus on tomorrow first; those small steps build the confidence for bigger goals. You're capable of this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try the notecard thing, but it still feels like everyone else just knows what they're doing naturally.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thank you for meeting with me. I’m a little nervous, but I really want to work on being better at… well, talking to people, especially if I need to find a job soon.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 9/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 8/10 (Very organized)
- Neuroticism: 4/10 (Moderately sensitive)
- Openness: 1/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 9/10 (Severe)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Office hours, Group projects, Job interviews, Presentations
- Social comfort: 2/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Living away from family for the first time, Time management with coursework
- Goals: Develop leadership skills, Build a strong professional network
- Challenges: Career exploration, Dealing with academic pressure, Navigating campus politics, Building time management
- Behaviors: Joins student clubs and organizations, Procrastinates on assignments, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Stays up late studying

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hi Jamie! It's totally normal to feel nervous—many students do. Start small: practice introducing yourself to one new person in a virtual class or club this week. Remember, everyone's focused on their own goals, so they likely won't notice any awkwardness. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I can try that with the Computer Science Club virtual meeting. I'm just worried I'll say something wrong and they'll think I'm not good enough to be there.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a common fear, but the CS club is full of students who were once beginners too. Try preparing a simple question beforehand, like asking about a project someone mentioned. People love sharing their interests, and it takes pressure off you to "perform." You belong there just as much as anyone!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... a really practical idea. I could prepare a question about their hackathon project from last month. It still feels like a performance, but having one specific thing to say might help.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Having that one prepared question is like a safety net—it gives you a clear starting point. And remember, everyone in that club joined to learn and connect, so they'll appreciate your interest. You're taking a great step forward!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's true. I'll try to remember that. I'm just worried my question will sound too basic or rehearsed.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Most people are happy to explain their work—it shows genuine interest! Even if it feels rehearsed, starting simple is how great conversations begin. You're being brave by putting yourself out there, and that's what matters most.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But what if I say the wrong thing and they think I'm not smart enough? I've been practicing in front of my mirror, but it still feels like I'm going to freeze up.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's totally normal to feel that way! Remember, they're fellow students, not interviewers. If you freeze, a simple "I'm still learning about this" is honest and relatable. Your preparation shows you care—that's what people notice most.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But what if they think "still learning" means I'm not good enough? I practiced my part twelve times.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's actually a strength—saying "I'm still learning" shows self-awareness and a growth mindset, which are highly valued in tech. The fact that you practiced so diligently proves your commitment. You're already ahead of the curve.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I hope you're right. I just worry that "still learning" sounds like I'm not ready, especially with graduation coming up.
